description: Architecturally consists of a nave with a gallery at the west end, chancel, north and south aisles. a chapel and south transept with a tower to the north. Three stained glass windows.

factsheet.heading: History
paragraphs: We were founded in 1908 as a Parish Church, paid for by members of Emmanuel Wimbledon, who themselves had only been going some 20 years, as a spin-off from St Mary’s Wimbledon.

In the spring of 1908 a marquee was erected on the corner of Ryfold Road and Strathmore Road and St Luke's was born. Worship continued during the summer while the parish hall was built of brick and slate, the congregation moving in during October of that year.

factsheet.heading: The Church Building
paragraphs: The church, which is Grade II listed, is set on a corner site fronting three roads in a suburban residential area. It was designed by Sir Thomas Jackson.

The church was completed in red brickwork with green slate roofs. It consists of a nave with gallery at the west end, chancel, north and south aisles, north chancel aisle (the present chapel) and south transept, a western narthex with entry vestibule and two side rooms and a tower to the north-west.

The land on which it was built was purchased on 14th April, 1908 from Ryan and Penfold for £1,285 including £10 interest. The builders were S Edwards & Company (hall and church foundations) and Kerridge & Shaw (kitchen, lobby and the main church structure). The hall's iron trusses were from Homan & Rogers and heating of the church and hall by Hoden & Sons.

The carved font and marble chancel floor cost £215. 12s. 6d from Farmer & Brindley Ltd. Amongst small sums, £27. 19s went to J Taylor & Co for the bell. With fittings, chairs etc included the total cost of the church was £9,109. 16s and the hall and kitchen £2,973. 3s. 6d.

location.address: St. Lukes Church, Ryfold Road, SW19 8BZ

name: St Luke's, Wimbledon Park
